text: remember this the running battles over
the poll-tax hated and hugely
controversial measure introduced by mrs.
Thatcher which eventually had to be
abandoned in the face of public anger
and yet if you ask most people what was
the poll tax actually about they
probably couldn't tell you but it
doesn't matter because it became more
than a policy it became a symbol of what
critics claimed was uncaring arrogant
out of touch government and the question
is this really could tax credits become
a poll tax mark too ok so the cuts to
tax credits haven't provoked riots in
the same way as the poll tax but they
have caused widespread anger why when i
went to the bird in the bush nursery in
south london to talk to some parents to
find out what difference would it make
to you if you were to lose tax credits
it could be two hundred pound 300-pound
what that impact it's going to be very I
it just meant own be able to provide
that well for my daughter at times to
say they're helping working parents I
don't see how that he's helping working
parents even at the moment as we're
getting it we're still struggling so how
is that going to help us the young
generation they want to you know buy
homes they want to you know study abroad
and stuff like that and all of that
costs money so if we're literally just
working to pay for our child care how
are we meant to you know move up in the
world and back at Westminster just like
with the poll tax the planned cuts to
tax credits have alarmed some Tory MPs I
am NOT interested in the color of the
government who created a bloated welfare
state that is in the past I don't care
whose fault it is but I do know one
thing it is not the fault of the
recipients of tax credits it's punishing
people who are going out there and
trying to work and do the right thing
and that just does not sit right with me
so that's something that I could not
support this policy was a mistake one
could only think that because I don't
think anybody in any party in this house
would deliberately I have impoverished
the working poor with dependent families
so why are some tour is so upset by
these cuts
to tax credits well again we have to go
back to mrs. Thatcher part of her
success lay in appealing to ordinary
working families Mr Cameron and Mr
Osborne would like to do the same to
make the tour is the party of working
people but it's difficult to do that
when you're cutting support for working
people they've been trying to portray
themselves as the party of people who
are doing the right thing going out to
work and now those people who are out to
work who only perhaps have one or two
hundred pounds at the end of the month
so that makes them feel clear and secure
are going to lose that and we're looking
at something like 3.2 million households
losing over 1,300 pounds amat you know
over the year that's a lot of money you
know if you're really going to argue for
you know the Conservative Party being a
party of the workers don't penalize
those who work it's a cry already taken
up by the Labour Party and some
newspapers so could tax credits be the
next poll tax well I've come to the
building where most MPs have their
offices to talk to the man who was mrs.
Thatcher's adviser at the time of the
poll tax and who actually warned her to
her face don't introduce the poll tax I
advised Margret Thatcher not to do it I
felt that without low modest numbers for
the tax it would not be easily saleable
to the British people but it was one of
those not very common occasions when she
didn't like my advice and we agreed to
differ looking back how much damage do
you think the poll tax did to mrs.
Thatcher knowing the Conservative Party
very well it was minority of MPs who are
worried about her European views how
European views are pretty popular with
most conservatives but the poll tax
wasn't the poll tax did become lethal
and toxic and her name was very strongly
associated with it how seriously do you
take the danger that the tax credit cuts
could become another poll tax I don't
think it will because the poll tax was
only deeply damaging once they did it
but back at the nursery in South London
the parents seemed in no
mood to forgive do you think the
decision that Mr Osborne is made on tax
credits I mean would you be able to
trust the Tories after this the next
election I'll find it very hard to even
pick you know a particular party I will
forgive him but again I'll be scared
that he might come up with anything to
just make us miserable when it comes to
middle class or lower class so damn
citizen it seems like we always the
people that always chase the bird and
the most a lot of families have kind of
gained from tax credits so why would you
say you want to take you away I feel
like they're not aware of people are
like working class people like us you
know I don't think there were of our
situations our way of living I just
scrap set in and perhaps the rau over

though is that whatever the money or
